Award.AwardTitle: GOALI / SusChEM: Structure-property relationships in metal-hydroxide oxygen-evolution electrocatalysts for alkaline-membrane-based water electrolysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this Grant Opportunities for Academic Liasons with Industry (GOALI) Award co-funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Division of Chemistry and the Office of Multidisciplinary Activities, Professor Shannon Boettcher from the University of Oregon will (1) study the mechanisms by which three-dimensional (3D) structure and local composition control the oxygen-evolution reaction (OER) activity in Ni hydroxide-based electrocatalysts and (2) identify the key factors affecting performance and durability of optimized Ni hydroxide OER catalysts in prototype alkaline-membrane electrolysis systems operating at practical current densities. The work will be carried out in collaboration with Dr. Kathy Ayers at Proton OnSite (Wallingford, CT). The focus on Ni-based OER catalysts is motivated by recent work in the Boettcher laboratory demonstrating that thin films of Ni-Fe hydroxides with 3D layered structures have higher per-atom activities than other known alkaline OER catalysts including IrO2. The team will also conduct outreach activities with local middle school students during furlough days. The middle school students will engage in hands-on energy storage and sustainability design-challenge activities on the University of Oregon campus.

The development of clean and sustainable energy sources is critical for both the economic and environmental vitality of human civilization. Renewable energy sources such as the sun and wind are intermittent and thus currently difficult and expensive to integrate with traditional energy sources in large amounts. One promising method to store intermittent renewable energy is by splitting water into hydrogen and oxygen gas. The hydrogen gas can be used as a sustainable carbon-free renewable fuel to replace fossil fuels. This research addresses an important challenge in designing water-splitting systems - the inefficiency of the oxygen production part of the reaction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Water electrolysis provides a near-term solution to green hydrogen production using any renewable (solar, wind) or traditional low-carbon electricity source (nuclear, hydroelectric). We study catalysts for advanced alkaline electrolysis technologies that combine the advantages of proton-exchange membrane (PEM) systems (i.e. high operating currents, ability for direct electrochemical hydrogen compression across the ion-selective solid-electrolyte membrane) with the ability to use low-cost, earth-abundant transition-metal oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) catalysts that are stable in alkaline conditions, but would corrode in acid. Funded by the NSF GOALI award, we built a lab-scale alkaline exchange membrane (AEM) electrolysis system, in collaboration with Dr. Kathy Ayers at Proton OnSite, that allows for rapid testing of the catalysts we develop under “industry-relevant” conditions.

To inform the design of improved AEM systems, we studied the fundamental behavior of electrocatalysts under alkaline conditions. Catalysts for the OER are particularly important, because they exhibit much larger overpotential losses than those for the HER. Despite >50 years of research, the factors governing the activity of OER catalysts are not well understood. The paradigm to describe activity trends and predict new catalysts is based on active-site intermediate binding energies. The experimental data that forms the basis for this paradigm and to which theory is compared, however, has been largely collected on poorly defined materials. This led us to question the validity of the established activity trends and their mechanistic interpretation.

Prior to the NSF GOALI award, we developed a thin-film electrochemical microbalance approach to studying OER electrocatalysis that minimizes confounding effects due to mass and electron transport through typical thick films or powders of varying surface area / porosity (10.1021/ja307507a). We developed methods to measure electrical conductivity in situ and use surface-analytical tools to clarify exactly how composition and structure evolves on active materials during OER. We discovered that oxides convert to (oxy)hydroxides and incorporate Fe impurities which create the active sites entirely responsible for OER in record-activity Ni(Fe)OOH catalysts (DOI: 10.1021/ja502379c, 10.1039/C4CC08670H, 10.1021/acscatal.5b02924, and 10.1021/acscatal.5b01551). We find similar behavior for Fe in Co-based catalysts, and show that, contrary to previous results, that Fe-free Co and Ni oxyhydroxides have inferior activity to pure FeOOH. FeOOH is a very poor electrical conductor until high overpotentials, which results in the low apparent activity (DOI: 10.1021/jacs.5b00281 and 10.1021/acs.chemmater.5b03404). These findings have reordered the fundamental activity trends across first-row transition metal OER catalysts in a way opposite of the established ones (DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpclett.5b01650). Based on these results, we proposed a new model for record activity Ni(Fe)OOH and Co(Fe)OOH OER catalysts where the Ni/Co oxyhydroxide serves as an electrically conductive, chemically stabilizing, porous host framework for possible Fe active sites (10.1021/acs.chemmater.5b03148). The details of the molecular mechanism remain to be understood.

The use-inspired basic research and industry-university collaboration that comprised this project created an excellent environment for training the next generation of scientists. As part of this project, 4 high school students, 6 undergraduates, and 5 main graduate students, and 4 visiting or rotating graduate students contributed to the research in substantial ways. 2 undergraduates/high-school-students co-authored publications. A new research-immersion freshman laboratory was piloted were students explored mixed metal water oxidation catalysts while earning credit for spring quarter of general chemistry laboratory; we are working to expand the pilot across the department and university. Researchers participated in an on-going middle school outreach program designed to provide underserved students with hands-on laboratory experiences and familiarity with the university environment. The partnership with Proton OnSite enabled UO graduate student internship experiences and facilitated knowledge transfer, both on fundamental aspects of oxygen catalysis from the University to the industry researchers and on practical aspects of electrolyzer design from industry to the University. The researchers on the project disseminated results broadly through 9 peer-reviewed publications and over 30 presentations at conferences or other institutions (including 2 visits to industry laboratories).

 

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2016
Modified by: Shannon W Boettcher
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Water electrolysis provides a near-term solution to green hydrogen production using any renewable (solar, wind) or traditional low-carbon electricity source (nuclear, hydroelectric). We study catalysts for advanced alkaline electrolysis technologies that combine the advantages of proton-exchange membrane (PEM) systems (i.e. high operating currents, ability for direct electrochemical hydrogen compression across the ion-selective solid-electrolyte membrane) with the ability to use low-cost, earth-abundant transition-metal oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) catalysts that are stable in alkaline conditions, but would corrode in acid. Funded by the NSF GOALI award, we built a lab-scale alkaline exchange membrane (AEM) electrolysis system, in collaboration with Dr. Kathy Ayers at Proton OnSite, that allows for rapid testing of the catalysts we develop under "industry-relevant" conditions. To inform the design of improved AEM systems, we studied the fundamental behavior of electrocatalysts under alkaline conditions. Catalysts for the OER are particularly important, because they exhibit much larger overpotential losses than those for the HER. Despite >50 years of research, the factors governing the activity of OER catalysts are not well understood. The researchers on the project disseminated results broadly through 9 peer-reviewed publications and over 30 presentations at conferences or other institutions (including 2 visits to industry laboratories).
